title: Revealed: More than half of wealthy Emiratis amassed their fortune from entrepreneurship
text:
Revealed: More than half of wealthy Emiratis amassed their fortune from entrepreneurship Article By Courtney Trenwith Monday, 5 October 2015 11:53 AM 
The UAE and Saudi Arabia account for nearly half of all ultra-wealthy Arabs, a new survey by Wealth-X has revealed. 
One in five, or 1,275, live in the UAE, worth a combined $255 billion. 
Saudi Arabia’s 1,495 ultra-high net worth individuals (UHNWIs) are worth a total $320 billion and account for 25 percent of the Middle East’s ultra-wealthy population. 
At a time when the region is encouraging greater diversification and entrepreneurship, more than half (57 percent) of the UAE’s UHNW population amassed their fortune through entrepreneurship, according to the survey. Eight percent fully inherited their fortune, and 35 percent partially inherited and grew their wealth. 
Only 3 percent of the UAE’s UHNWIs made their wealth through oil, gas and consumable fuels, while industrial conglomerates proved the most significant source of the UAE’s wealth, as the main sector of investment for 20 percent of UNHWIs. 
There are more UNHWIs in Dubai (495) than in Abu Dhabi (450). 
In total, the Middle East has nearly 6,000 UHNWIs, worth about $995 billion. 
Saudi Arabia has the world’s 17th highest UHNW population, followed by the UAE (22nd) and Kuwait (32nd). 
“Despite the UAE equity market suffering declines of nearly 20 percent in the last year, our study shows that UHNW individuals in the country have defied this economic backdrop to record further increases in their fortunes in 2015, highlighting the ability of the world’s wealthiest individuals to continue to create new wealth,” Wealth-X Middle East director David Awit said.
